head.title: F.I.T. Plans to Close a Street, But Neighbors Head to Barricades

hedline.hl1: F.I.T. Plans to Close a Street, But Neighbors Head to Barricades

abstract.p: Residents and local businesses strongly oppose plan by New York's Fashion Institute of Technology to close off 27th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues and create pedestrian mall, closed to all but emergency traffic; drawing; chart (M)

block.p: The idea sounds charming: close off the street, lay down brick pavement, plant shady trees and transform the block into a quiet haven from the rest of the city.

But the plan, proposed by the Fashion Institute of Technology for a stretch of 27th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, met with strong opposition from residents and businesses at a hearing on Wednesday.
The idea sounds charming: close off the street, lay down brick pavement, plant shady trees and transform the block into a quiet haven from the rest of the city.

But the plan, proposed by the Fashion Institute of Technology for a stretch of 27th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, met with strong opposition from residents and businesses at a hearing on Wednesday.

The block is already an informal campus for the university's 12,000 students. A hulking concrete catwalk, embossed with its name, welcomes visitors on Seventh Avenue. Since 1979, traffic on the westbound street has been restricted on weekdays between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m.
As part of a major renovation, the institute wants to seal off traffic completely, except for emergency vehicles, and create a landscaped pedestrian mall.
''The plan provides the college with an enriched identity by integrating our dormitories and academic facilities,'' said Harvey Spector, vice president of finance and operations.

But the mall would only cover the eastern two-thirds of the street, where the university's huge buildings are clustered. The western part of the street, where there are four residential and commercial high-rises, would become two-way, for pick-ups and deliveries.
Although residents were initially favorable, many now say they oppose the plan.

''We believe this proposal will only benefit F.I.T. and turn our western end of the block into a noisy, chaotic and potentially dangerous loading zone,'' said Gail Dobish, vice president of the 27th Street Block Association.
Critics also said the proposed traffic turnaround is too narrow to accommodate the 70 small businesses on the block.
''If there's one truck in there, the whole road will be backed up,'' said Joe Martinow, manager of Fashion Design Books, a supplier of students' textbooks.

To illustrate the point, Julius Panero, a former design professor at F.I.T. and owner of a building on the block, brought a couple of matchbox cars to the meeting to demonstrate the difficulty of negotiating a three-point turn inside the 50-foot-wide cul-de-sac.

Community Board 5, which sponsored the hearing, rejected the design on Thursday. But the $1.5 million project has been approved by the city's Department of Transportation and by the Dormitory Authority, which oversees college buildings in the state.
Mr. Spector said that the university had incorporated many suggestions from the community board and he hoped construction would begin this year.
